articles.headline: In McConnell’s Own State, Fear and Confusion Over Health Care Bill
articles.snippet: Medicaid covers nearly one in three in Kentucky, and people here don’t know what to oppose more: Obamacare or Republicans’ cure for it.
articles.abstract: Medicaid covers nearly one in three in Kentucky, and people here don’t know what to oppose more: Obamacare or Republicans’ cure for it.
articles.lead_paragraph: WHITESBURG, Ky. — Dewey Gorman, a 59-year-old banker who has struggled with opioid addiction, had just gotten out of the hospital in this tiny central Appalachian city when he heard the word from Washington: His fellow Kentuckian, Senator Mitch McConnell, had delayed a vote to repeal the Affordable Care Act. He felt torn about that.

articles.headline: As Affordable Care Act Repeal Teeters, Prospects for Bipartisanship Build
articles.snippet: While he presses Republicans to get behind his bill for undoing Obamacare, Senator Mitch McConnell is also raising the specter of bringing Democrats into Senate health care talks.
articles.abstract: While he presses Republicans to get behind his bill for undoing Obamacare, Senator Mitch McConnell is also raising the specter of bringing Democrats into Senate health care talks.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With his bill to repeal the Affordable Care Act in deep trouble, Mitch McConnell, the Senate majority leader, raised an alternate possibility on Tuesday: Either Republicans come together, or he would have to work with Democrats to shore up the deteriorating health law.
articles.byline: By Robert Pear and Thomas Kaplan

articles.headline: Staples to Sell for $6.9 Billion, and Its New Owner Has an Uphill Battle
articles.snippet: The private equity firm Sycamore Partners is adding the office supply chain to its portfolio of retailers.
articles.abstract: The private equity firm Sycamore Partners is adding the office supply chain to its portfolio of retailers.
articles.lead_paragraph: As online shopping claims ever more casualties, Staples, a mainstay of office supplies, has agreed to sell itself to a private equity firm.
articles.byline: By David Gelles and Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Ukraine Cyberattack Was Meant to Paralyze, not Profit, Evidence Shows
articles.snippet: Pinpointing the initial targets of the assault — Ukrainian accountants who use a tax preparation software required by the government — was a major clue.
articles.abstract: Pinpointing the initial targets of the assault — Ukrainian accountants who use a tax preparation software required by the government — was a major clue.
articles.lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — The day started like most for Roman N. Klimenko, an accountant in Kiev who had just settled in at his desk, typing at a computer keyboard and drinking coffee. He was unaware that concealed within his tax preparation software lurked a ticking bomb.

articles.headline: Hacks Raise Fear Over N.S.A.’s Hold on Cyberweapons
articles.snippet: Hackers in two global attacks have used cyberweapons stolen from a dangerous collection that had been amassed by the agency.
articles.abstract: Hackers in two global attacks have used cyberweapons stolen from a dangerous collection that had been amassed by the agency.
articles.lead_paragraph: Twice in the past month, National Security Agency cyberweapons stolen from its arsenal have been turned against two very different partners of the United States — Britain and Ukraine.
articles.byline: By Nicole Perlroth and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: Amid Turkey’s Purge, a Renewed Attack on Kurdish Culture
articles.snippet: The authorities have fired people from jobs promoting Kurdish culture, removed statues of Kurdish heroes, shut Kurdish media and jailed pro-Kurdish journalists.
articles.abstract: The authorities have fired people from jobs promoting Kurdish culture, removed statues of Kurdish heroes, shut Kurdish media and jailed pro-Kurdish journalists.
articles.lead_paragraph: DIYARBAKIR, Turkey — Gosto’s kebab shop is not the only diner on its block, let alone on its street. It is, however, the one that perhaps reveals most about the threat to Kurdish culture.

articles.headline: Once a Model City, Hong Kong Is in Trouble
articles.snippet: When the British left 20 years ago, Hong Kong was seen as a rare blend of East and West that China might seek to emulate. Now, increasingly, it’s a cautionary tale.
articles.abstract: When the British left 20 years ago, Hong Kong was seen as a rare blend of East and West that China might seek to emulate. Now, increasingly, it’s a cautionary tale.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — When Hong Kong returned to Chinese rule two decades ago, the city was seen as a model of what China might one day become: prosperous, modern, international, with the broad protections of the rule of law.

articles.headline: Setback for Murdoch in $15 Billion Sky Takeover
articles.snippet: The British authorities on Thursday asked regulators to further examine 21st Century Fox’s deal for the European satellite giant.
articles.abstract: The British authorities on Thursday asked regulators to further examine 21st Century Fox’s deal for the European satellite giant.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years, Rupert Murdoch has tried to cement his legacy by adding Sky, the European satellite giant, to his global media empire. That quest was delayed once again Thursday as the British authorities asked regulators to further examine whether the $15 billion deal would give the Murdoch family too much control over the country’s media.
articles.byline: By Mark Scott and Emily Steel

articles.headline: Vatican Sex Abuse Scandal Reveals Blind Spot for Francis
articles.snippet: The pope spoke of committees to safeguard children, tribunals to try bishops and a “zero tolerance” policy for offending priests. It hasn’t quite worked out that way.
articles.abstract: The pope spoke of committees to safeguard children, tribunals to try bishops and a “zero tolerance” policy for offending priests. It hasn’t quite worked out that way.
articles.lead_paragraph: VATICAN CITY — Pope Francis came to power promising not only to create a more inclusive church and to clean up an ossified Vatican bureaucracy, but also to remove the stain of child sex abuse.
articles.byline: By Jason Horowitz and Laurie Goodstein

articles.headline: Tech, Fed, Trump: So Many Reasons to Worry About the Market
articles.snippet: President Trump has taken credit for a surging market this year. But tech stocks, the Fed and the president himself could change that picture.
articles.abstract: President Trump has taken credit for a surging market this year. But tech stocks, the Fed and the president himself could change that picture.
articles.lead_paragraph: Throughout the turbulence of his first months in office, President Trump has been able to point to one bastion of support: the stock market. Earlier this month he tweeted the “great economic news” he thinks the mainstream media has been ignoring: The Dow Jones industrial average was up 16 percent and the Nasdaq up 19.5 percent since his election. Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross maintained that the Trump administration had bestowed $4 trillion in gains on investors.

articles.headline: Trump Mocks Mika Brzezinski; Says She Was ‘Bleeding Badly From a Face-Lift’
articles.snippet: The president used Twitter to taunt Ms. Brzezinski and her MSNBC co-host, Joe Scarborough, referring to them as “low I.Q. Crazy Mika, along with Psycho Joe.”
articles.abstract: The president used Twitter to taunt Ms. Brzezinski and her MSNBC co-host, Joe Scarborough, referring to them as “low I.Q. Crazy Mika, along with Psycho Joe.”
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump lashed out Thursday at the appearance and intellect of Mika Brzezinski, a co-host of MSNBC’s “Morning Joe,” drawing condemnation from his fellow Republicans and reigniting the controversy over his attitudes toward women that nearly derailed his candidacy last year.
articles.byline: By Glenn Thrush and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: U.S. Seeks to Keep Closer Tabs on Chinese Money in America
articles.snippet: Laws sought by Trump administration officials and some politicians would overhaul how the United States vets deals, especially ones with technological and military ramifications.
articles.abstract: Laws sought by Trump administration officials and some politicians would overhaul how the United States vets deals, especially ones with technological and military ramifications.
articles.lead_paragraph: When President Trump talked tough about China’s economic impact on America during the campaign, he criticized its trade policies and its approach to its currency.
articles.byline: By Paul Mozur and Cecilia Kang
